  • are familiar with Aalto University, your own degree programme, major, and academic advisor 
  • have improved both your academic and intercultural skills to be able to work and collaborate in a multicultural and multidisciplinary learning environment 
  • Know the principles of good study practices at Aalto university
  • Know what academic integrity is at Aalto University and how to adopt it
learningOutcomes.en:
The course aims to offer all the information necessary for success in studies at Aalto University.  Upon completion of the course, you:
  • have acquired knowledge about the degree requirements, the minors studies and are able to make a target-oriented study plan
  • are familiar with the services offered by the university 
  • know the study-related IT-systems and have the ability to use them
  • are familiar with effective learning and study skills and are able to use them in real life
  • are familiar with Aalto University, your own degree programme, major, and academic advisor 
  • have improved both your academic and intercultural skills to be able to work and collaborate in a multicultural and multidisciplinary learning environment 
  • Know the principles of good study practices at Aalto university
  • Know what academic integrity is at Aalto University and how to adopt it

content.fi:
The course takes the whole first academic year. The course consists of lectures, active workshops, get-togethers, assignments, field visits and other activities all designed to provide students with comprehensive insights that will help identify and strengthen the skills and knowledge needed to achieve and have a positive study experience at Aalto University. The course consists of four parts:
  1. Orientation week events
  2. Lectures once a week (during period I)
  3. Get-togethers and academic advising meetings organized by the BSc programme (throughout the first academic year)
  4. Preparing a complete personal study plan for your BSc degree

learningOutcomes.fi: The students will learn how various materials behave at low temperatures, what are their physical properties, and how to construct a successful experiment using low-temperature techniques.
learningOutcomes.sv: The students will learn how various materials behave at low temperatures, what are their physical properties, and how to construct a successful experiment using low-temperature techniques.
learningOutcomes.en: The students will learn how various materials behave at low temperatures, what are their physical properties, and how to construct a successful experiment using low-temperature techniques.

content.fi: Behavior of matter at low temperatures; modern refrigerators and submilliKelvin apparata; ultrasensitive measurement techniques; thermometry; noise and electromagntic interference; applications of nuclear magnetic resonance at low temperatures.

content.en: Behavior of matter at low temperatures; modern refrigerators and submilliKelvin apparata; ultrasensitive measurement techniques; thermometry; noise and electromagntic interference; applications of nuclear magnetic resonance at low temperatures.

learningOutcomes.fi:
The students will learn how machine learning used in different biomedical applications.
Students will get training on scientific work, presenting research and giving feedback on other student's work.
learningOutcomes.sv: The students will learn how machine learning used in different biomedical applications.Students will get training on scientific work, presenting research and giving feedback on other student's work.
learningOutcomes.en: The students will learn how machine learning used in different biomedical applications.Students will get training on scientific work, presenting research and giving feedback on other student's work.

content.fi: Machine learning is one of the key technologies in data-driven biomedicine, used in numerous tools and applications. This course probes the state of the art in selected machine learning problems and the associated methods in biomedicine, through introductory lectures and student's own work in selected topics.

Students can attend the Deep Learning course and this course during the same spring.Recommended prerequisites: - Probabilistic Machine Learning (CS-E4825) or Machine Learning: Advanced Probabilistic methods (CS-E4820)), - Supervised Machine Learning (CS-E4715) or Machine Learning: Supervised Methods (CS-E4710)) - Knowledge of statistics and probabilistic modeling

learningOutcomes.fi: Students will learn the general principles of deep generative modeling and uncertainty quantification as well as the current deep generative modeling methods. After the course, students will be able to apply the methods to real-world data sets and study the topic further.
learningOutcomes.sv: Students will learn the general principles of deep generative modeling and uncertainty quantification as well as the current deep generative modeling methods. After the course, students will be able to apply the methods to real-world data sets and study the topic further.
learningOutcomes.en: Students will learn the general principles of deep generative modeling and uncertainty quantification as well as the current deep generative modeling methods. After the course, students will be able to apply the methods to real-world data sets and study the topic further.

content.fi:
Fundamental and current topics of generative modeling and uncertainty quantification. Both methodological and implementing aspects are part of the course contents.  Topics include
  • Monte Carlo methods
  • Divergence measures
  • Variational inference and autoencoders
  • Deep state-space models
  • Diffusion models
  • Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
content.sv:
Fundamental and current topics of generative modeling and uncertainty quantification. Both methodological and implementing aspects are part of the course contents.  Topics include

  • Divergence measures
  • Variational inference and autoencoders
  • Deep state-space models
  • Diffusion models
  • Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
content.en:

  • Diffusion models
  • Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)

learningOutcomes.fi:
1. Understand how important problems arising from diverse fields can be modeled by means of operations research;
2. Know main modeling frameworks of operations research and their applications;
3. Know how to use software for modeling and solving operations research problems.
learningOutcomes.sv: 1. Understand how important problems arising from diverse fields can be modeled by means of operations research;2. Know main modeling frameworks of operations research and their applications;3. Know how to use software for modeling and solving operations research problems.
learningOutcomes.en: 1. Understand how important problems arising from diverse fields can be modeled by means of operations research;2. Know main modeling frameworks of operations research and their applications;3. Know how to use software for modeling and solving operations research problems.

content.fi: In this course, the student will learn how to analyze and formulate problems and how they can be solved. The modeling frameworks discussed in this lecture include linear and discrete optimization. At the end of this course, it is expected that the student will be capable of analysing the main characteristics of a problem, model it using varying paradigms and choosing a suitable solution method.

content.fi: Advanced course which gives hands-on experience on programming real-time audio signal processing systems. The basic module of 3 ECTS consists of smaller assignments and a small project whereas for 5 ECTS there is also a larger individual project. Both the assignments and projects will be implemented in C++, but the course will start with an introduction to C++ such that basic programming skills are sufficient programming background for this course.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: There are no mandatory prerequisites for this course. However, students are recommended to have completed CS-E4340 Cryptography D or otherwise have acquired basic knowledge in cryptography. Students are expected to be comfortable with mathematical reasoning, reading and writing formal definitions and proofs, and analysing behaviours of algorithms. Students with background knowledge in relevant areas (linear algebra, abstract algebra, number theory, theory of computation, algorithms, complexity theory, cyber security, etc.) will be able to strengthen and apply their knowledge in this course. The course is suitable for advanced bachelor, master, and doctoral students. We recommend the course especially for those interested in a bachelor or master thesis in the area of cryptography.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After completing this course, students should have acquired the following skills:
- Basic understanding of core public-key cryptographic primitives, e.g. public-key encryption, signatures, commitments, and argument systems.
- How to construct core public-key cryptographic primitives over algebraic structures.
- How to reason about the security of constructions based on the conjectured hardness of computational problems over algebraic structures.
- How to securely compose core public-key cryptographic primitives to build advanced primitives, e.g. advanced encryption schemes, privacy-preserving signature schemes, protocols for computational tasks with privacy guarantees.
- Familiarity of security and privacy goals achievable via cryptographic techniques in realistic privacy-preserving applications.
learningOutcomes.sv: After completing this course, students should have acquired the following skills:- Basic understanding of core public-key cryptographic primitives, e.g. public-key encryption, signatures, commitments, and argument systems.- How to construct core public-key cryptographic primitives over algebraic structures.- How to reason about the security of constructions based on the conjectured hardness of computational problems over algebraic structures.- How to securely compose core public-key cryptographic primitives to build advanced primitives, e.g. advanced encryption schemes, privacy-preserving signature schemes, protocols for computational tasks with privacy guarantees.- Familiarity of security and privacy goals achievable via cryptographic techniques in realistic privacy-preserving applications.
learningOutcomes.en: After completing this course, students should have acquired the following skills:- Basic understanding of core public-key cryptographic primitives, e.g. public-key encryption, signatures, commitments, and argument systems.- How to construct core public-key cryptographic primitives over algebraic structures.- How to reason about the security of constructions based on the conjectured hardness of computational problems over algebraic structures.- How to securely compose core public-key cryptographic primitives to build advanced primitives, e.g. advanced encryption schemes, privacy-preserving signature schemes, protocols for computational tasks with privacy guarantees.- Familiarity of security and privacy goals achievable via cryptographic techniques in realistic privacy-preserving applications.

content.fi:
This is an intermediate-level course on cryptography, with focus on public-key, application-oriented cryptographic primitives. It covers definitions and constructions of core and advanced public-key primitives, and their applications in privacy-preserving systems.
In particular, we cover the following core primitives:- Public-key encryption- Signatures- Commitments- Zero-knowledge arguments
We will also cover advanced primitives, with focus on their applications in privacy-preserving systems. The exact list of primitives and applications may differ in each instance of the course. Some examples are given below:
- Identity-based encryption and attributed-based encryption: Cryptographic access control- Group signatures, ring signatures, blind signatures, and anonymous credentials: Anonymous authentication- Searchable encryption, and oblivious random access machine: Searching and operating over encrypted database- Private information retrieval: Private queries over public databases- Proof of work, proof of stake, ring confidential transactions, coin mixing, swapping: Cryptocurrencies, smart contracts, and distributed anonymous applications- Password-based cryptography: Enhanced password-based authentication

We will also cover advanced primitives, with focus on their applications in privacy-preserving systems. The exact list of primitives and applications may differ in each instance of the course. Some examples are given below:
- Identity-based encryption and attributed-based encryption: Cryptographic access control- Group signatures, ring signatures, blind signatures, and anonymous credentials: Anonymous authentication- Searchable encryption, and oblivious random access machine: Searching and operating over encrypted database- Private information retrieval: Private queries over public databases- Proof of work, proof of stake, ring confidential transactions, coin mixing, swapping: Cryptocurrencies, smart contracts, and distributed anonymous applications- Password-based cryptography: Enhanced password-based authentication

assesmentMethods.fi:
The course is pass/fail, and to pass, one is required to collect a certain amount of participation points (for the exact thresholds for each teaching period and overall course, see MyCourses page of the course instance in question). 
Participation points are primarily obtained via submitting solutions to exercises (there is no exam), and it is possible to pass the course by only submitting exercises. 
In some course instances, there might be additional ways to obtain participation points. See MyCourses page of the course instance in question for details.

learningOutcomes.fi: Learning the core concepts of complexity and system science—causal feedback, systems thinking, emergence, self-organization, the edge of chaos, autopoiesis, stigmergy, the structure and function of networks, and computational explanations of natural phenomena. Learning how to identify, analyze, and simulate these for real systems. To have a historical overview of the development of these ideas.

learningOutcomes.en: Learning the core concepts of complexity and system science—causal feedback, systems thinking, emergence, self-organization, the edge of chaos, autopoiesis, stigmergy, the structure and function of networks, and computational explanations of natural phenomena. content.fi:
• The history of complexity science and related developments: tektology, cybernetics, general systems theory, systems dynamics, the Austrian school of economics, hierarchy theory, chaos theory, self-organized criticality, complex adaptive systems, artificial life.
  • Tools and models: Primarily agent-based models and cellular automata, but also about systems dynamics and network analysis.
  • Phenomena and examples: Pattern formation, fractals, critical phenomena, space syntax, traffic models, evolutionary game theory.

learningOutcomes.fi: The goal of the course is to learn about the guiding information security and technical principles behind cybersecurity governance and management, and apply them critically to different types of systems, such as operational technology (industrial automation) and machine learning systems cybersecurity. The student will learn about cybersecurity risk management frameworks and architectural approaches to build and assess cybersecurity within an organization.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Students should either (1) complete the follow courses at Aalto: CS-C3140 Operating Systems, CS-A1155 Databases for Data Science, CS-C3150 Software Engineering, CS-E4110 Concurrent Programming, CS-E4190 Cloud Software and Systems or (2) demonstrate the understanding of concepts and technologies in operating systems, databases, networks, distributed systems, software engineering and virtualization and container techniques. Furthermore, students must program well with at least two programming languages in C++, C, Java, Rust, Python and Go. Prerequisites will be checked through students' completed courses and/or through pre-assignment/interview with responsible teachers. It is an advantage for the study if students have finished CS-E4640 Big Data Platforms and CS-E4660 Advanced Topics in Software Systems, or familiar with working in large-scale computing environments.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After completing the course, students will be able to
  • Define the requirements, building blocks, and challenges when architecting, building and managing a large-scale data-center infrastructure for distributed systems and databases.
  • Know the design principles and implement code for engineering scalable data-intensive systems and their applications; analyze the full system stack for managing and scheduling data-center resources in relation to distributed storage, coordination and computation.
  • Critically assess the trade-offs between different requirements when designing scalable distributed systems; Understand the trade-offs in converting between data models and database tools.
  • Understand new data models and new storage technologies, as well as their impacts on query execution, database systems, cloud platforms, data processing pipeline, and modern machine learning systems.        
  • Discuss, compare and criticize the state-of-the-art research approaches presented in research papers targeting distributed systems, databases and machine learning systems.

  • Critically assess the trade-offs between different requirements when designing scalable distributed systems; Understand the trade-offs in converting between data models and database tools.
  • Understand new data models and new storage technologies, as well as their impacts on query execution, database systems, cloud platforms, data processing pipeline, and modern machine learning systems.        
  • Discuss, compare and criticize the state-of-the-art research approaches presented in research papers targeting distributed systems, databases and machine learning systems.

  • Know the design principles and implement code for engineering scalable data-intensive systems and their applications; analyze the full system stack for managing and scheduling data-center resources in relation to distributed storage, coordination and computation.
  • Critically assess the trade-offs between different requirements when designing scalable distributed systems; Understand the trade-offs in converting between data models and database tools.
  • Understand new data models and new storage technologies, as well as their impacts on query execution, database systems, cloud platforms, data processing pipeline, and modern machine learning systems.        
  • Discuss, compare and criticize the state-of-the-art research approaches presented in research papers targeting distributed systems, databases and machine learning systems.

content.fi: This course is on the design and implementation of scalable data management systems. Topics include data-center technologies, data models (relational, document, key/value), storage models, query languages, storage architectures, indexing, query processing and optimization, in-memory databases, distributed storage, distributed coordination (consensus protocols and use-cases), transaction processing and concurrency control, new storage media, and parallel architectures (multicores/multi-socket/chiplet), as well as studies on open-source/commercial distributed database systems to illustrate these techniques and trade-offs.

Topics include data-center technologies, data models (relational, document, key/value), storage models, query languages, storage architectures, indexing, query processing and optimization, in-memory databases, distributed storage, distributed coordination (consensus protocols and use-cases), transaction processing and concurrency control, new storage media, and parallel architectures (multicores/multi-socket/chiplet), as well as studies on open-source/commercial distributed database systems to illustrate these techniques and trade-offs.

learningOutcomes.fi:
• To view the energy world from a systemic innovation perspective and to understand innovation and the commercialization of new innovations in the energy field
  • To understand the key changes in the energy field, such as the transformation of industrial energy supply, the fundamental shift in electricity production, sustainable mobility, and how energy changes from a user perspective, and which opportunities for innovation exist as a result of these changes
  • To get to know companies and other organizations from the energy field as well as individual representatives from these companies and organizations
  • To understand and analyze real-life business problems in the energy field and to be able to provide viable, feasible and valuable solutions for these problems and to be able to defend the recommended solutions
learningOutcomes.sv:
• To view the energy world from a systemic innovation perspective and to understand innovation and the commercialization of new innovations in the energy field
  • To understand the key changes in the energy field, such as the transformation of industrial energy supply, the fundamental shift in electricity production, sustainable mobility, and how energy changes from a user perspective, and which opportunities for innovation exist as a result of these changes
  • To get to know companies and other organizations from the energy field as well as individual representatives from these companies and organizations
  • To understand and analyze real-life business problems in the energy field and to be able to provide viable, feasible and valuable solutions for these problems and to be able to defend the recommended solutions
learningOutcomes.en:
• To view the energy world from a systemic innovation perspective and to understand innovation and the commercialization of new innovations in the energy field
  • To understand the key changes in the energy field, such as the transformation of industrial energy supply, the fundamental shift in electricity production, sustainable mobility, and how energy changes from a user perspective, and which opportunities for innovation exist as a result of these changes
  • To get to know companies and other organizations from the energy field as well as individual representatives from these companies and organizations
  • To understand and analyze real-life business problems in the energy field and to be able to provide viable, feasible and valuable solutions for these problems and to be able to defend the recommended solutions

content.fi: The course offers a deep-dive into energy-related industries and an opportunity to get to know and develop contacts with representatives from companies and other organizations. Students work in multidisciplinary teams to tackle innovation challenges with companies or organizations in the energy field. The students will have mentors from the industry and take part in social activities and visits to companies.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: You are expected to have a good command of probability theory (MS-E1600 Probability Theory) and linear algebra (MS-C1324 Linear Algebra), and some familiarity with multivariate statistics (MS-E2112 Multivariate Statistical Analysis).

learningOutcomes.fi:
This course introduces you to mathematical concepts and methods used in analysing high-dimensional data. What you will learn:
  • Formulate sparse high-dimensional statistical models mathematically.
  • Apply random matrix theory to understand statistical features in high dimensions.
  • Utilise low-dimensional structures (sparsity, low rank) to tame the curse of dimensionality.
learningOutcomes.sv:

  • Utilise low-dimensional structures (sparsity, low rank) to tame the curse of dimensionality.
learningOutcomes.en:

content.fi:
Modern applications of data science and machine learning commonly deal with high-dimensional data in which the number variables is large. This course focuses on mathematical concepts developed for understanding the interplay of dimensions, sparsity, and complexity in such datasets and associated stochastic models. Key concepts:
  • Sub-Gaussian and sub-exponential probability distributions.
  • Concentration inequalities of random matrices and their singular values.
  • Random projections in Euclidean spaces.
  • Covering numbers and metric entropy of sets.
  • Applications to dimension reduction, sparse regression, and network clustering.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssin myötä opiskelija:
  1. Osaa kriittisesti arvioida tuotannon ja liiketoiminnan kestävyyttä sekä suunnitella strategioita, joilla pyritään kehittämään organisaatioita ja niiden prosesseja kohti ympäristövaikutusten vähentämistä ja sosiaalista vastuunkantoa. 
  2. Pystyy selittämään liiketoiminnan osa-alueiden sekä johtamisen merkitystä ja keskeisiä yhtymäkohtia kestävään kehitykseen.
  3. Ymmärtää kestävän talouden kokonaiskuvaa ja tulevaisuusskenaarioita, ja osaa kuvata lainsäädännön ja innovaatioiden merkitystä kestävyyden edistämisessä.
  4. Jäsentää omaa rooliaan kestävän kehityksen tavoitteiden edistäjänä ja monimutkaisten yhteiskunnallisten ongelmien ratkaisijana yhdessä muiden toimijoiden kanssa.
learningOutcomes.sv:
Efter kursen kommer studenten att kunna:
  1. Kritiskt bedöma hållbarheten inom produktion och affärsverksamhet samt utforma strategier för att utveckla organisationer och deras processer mot minskade miljöpåverkningar och ökat socialt ansvarstagande.
  2. Förklara betydelsen och centrala kopplingar mellan olika affärsområden och ledning i relation till hållbar utveckling.
  3. Förstå helhetsbilden av hållbar ekonomi och framtida scenarier samt kunna beskriva lagstiftningens och innovationernas betydelse för främjande av hållbarhet.
  4. Analysera sin egen roll som främjare av hållbarhetsmål och lösare av komplexa samhällsproblem i samarbete med andra aktörer.
learningOutcomes.en:
As a result of the course, the student will be able to:
  1. Critically assess the sustainability of production and business and design strategies aimed at developing organizations and their processes towards reducing environmental impacts and taking social responsibility.
  2. Explain the significance and key intersections of business areas and management in relation to sustainable development.
  3. Understand the big picture of sustainable economy and future scenarios, and be able to describe the significance of legislation and innovations in promoting sustainability.
  4. Analyze their own role as a promoter of sustainable development goals and as a solver of complex societal problems, working together with other stakeholders.

content.fi:
Kestävä kehitys sisältyy kokonaisvaltaisesti liiketoiminnan eri osa-alueisiin. Kestävyysajattelu, -vaatimukset ja lainsäädäntö eivät ainoastaan luo uusia liiketoiminnan mahdollisuuksia. Ne edellyttävät merkittävää sopeutumista myös nykyiseltä liiketoiminnalta, järjestelmiltä, johtamiselta ja organisoitumiselta – kulutuksesta puhumattakaan. Kurssin lähtökohtana on, että yrityksillä ja muilla organisaatioilla on keskeinen yhteiskunnallinen rooli kestävän muutoksen ajureina.
Kurssi tarjoaa opiskelijoille kokonaisymmärryksen ja perustan kestävän liiketoiminnan periaatteista ja käytännöistä. Se antaa opiskelijoille valmiuksia analysoida ja suunnitella kestäviä periaatteita noudattavia ratkaisuja. Kurssi luo vahvat perusteet kestävän liiketoiminnan johtamiselle, korostaen ekologisesti ja sosiaalisesti kestävää kehitystä liiketoiminnan eri osa-alueilla.
Kurssilla käsitellään muun muassa seuraavia kysymyksiä: Mitä tarkoittavat kestävästi toimiva talous ja liiketoiminta, ja miten niitä ohjataan? Miten kestävyys ilmenee organisaatioiden eri osa-alueilla, kuten tuotantoprosesseissa, investoinneissa, johtamisessa ja strategiatyössä? Kuinka kiertotalous, kestävä palvelutalous ja innovaatiot vaikuttavat kestävän liiketoiminnan edistämiseen?
content.sv:
Hållbar utveckling inkluderas heltäckande i olika delar av verksamheten. Hållbarhetstänkande, -krav och lagstiftning skapar inte bara nya affärsmöjligheter. De kräver också betydande anpassning från befintlig verksamhet, system, ledning och organisering - inte minst när det gäller konsumtion. Utgångspunkten för kursen är att företag och andra organisationer har en central samhällelig roll som drivkrafter för hållbar förändring.
Kursen ger studenterna en övergripande förståelse och grund för principer och metoder för hållbart företagande. Den ger studenterna färdigheter att analysera och planera lösningar som följer hållbara principer. Kursen skapar starka grunder för ledning av hållbart företagande, med tonvikt på ekologisk och social hållbarhet inom olika affärsområden.
Kursen behandlar bland annat följande frågor: Vad innebär hållbar ekonomi och företagande, och hur styrs de? Hur manifesteras hållbarhet inom olika områden av organisationer, såsom produktionsprocesser, investeringar, ledning och strategiarbete? Hur påverkar cirkulär ekonomi, hållbar tjänsteekonomi och innovationer främjandet av hållbart företagande?
content.en:
Sustainable development is comprehensively integrated into various aspects of business. Sustainability thinking, requirements, and legislation not only create new business opportunities but also require significant adaptation from existing business, systems, management, and organization – not to mention consumption. The starting point of the course is that companies and other organizations play a crucial societal role as drivers of sustainable change.
The course provides students with a comprehensive understanding and foundation of the principles and practices of sustainable business. It equips students with the ability to analyze and plan solutions that adhere to sustainable principles. The course establishes a strong foundation for sustainable business management, emphasizing ecological and social sustainability across various business areas.
The course addresses questions such as: What does a sustainably functioning economy and business mean, and how are they guided? How does sustainability manifest itself in different areas of organizations, such as production processes, investments, management, and strategic work? How do circular economy, sustainable service economy, and innovations contribute to the promotion of sustainable business?

name.fi: Research Project on Data Intensive Computing D, Luento-opetus
name.sv: Research Project on Data Intensive Computing D, Föreläsning
name.en: Research Project on Data Intensive Computing D, Lecture

workload.fi: Weekly meeting (12*2=24), self-study of the materials (15), project development (72), preparing and presenting the final work (12), participation in other students’ presentations (22).
workload.sv: Weekly meeting (12*2=24), self-study of the materials (15), project development (72), preparing and presenting the final work (12), participation in other students’ presentations (22).

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Students should have good knowledge about distributed computing, cloud computing, data management, and high performance computing. Recommended courses/knowledge acquisition to be completed before the course: CS-E4190: Cloud Software and Systems CS-E4690: Programming Parallel Supercomputers CS-E4640: Big Data Platforms CS-E4780: Scalable Systems and Data Management

learningOutcomes.fi:
After completing the course, students will be able to
  • Acquire hands-on experience on working large-scale data-intensive computing environments, including software stacks, data management and hardware in data centers.  
  • Understand how to translate the real-world problem into requirements for data-intensive applications and solve them by leveraging distributed systems/big data systems/machine learning systems on top high-performance computing (HPC) clusters and supercomputers
  • Apply studied frameworks and techniques to build real-world data intensive solutions and to systematically evaluate these solutions.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After completing the course, students will be able to
  • Acquire hands-on experience on working large-scale data-intensive computing environments, including software stacks, data management and hardware in data centers.  
  • Understand how to translate the real-world problem into requirements for data-intensive applications and solve them by leveraging distributed systems/big data systems/machine learning systems on top high-performance computing (HPC) clusters and supercomputers
  • Apply studied frameworks and techniques to build real-world data intensive solutions and to systematically evaluate these solutions.
learningOutcomes.en:
After completing the course, students will be able to
  • Acquire hands-on experience on working large-scale data-intensive computing environments, including software stacks, data management and hardware in data centers.  
  • Understand how to translate the real-world problem into requirements for data-intensive applications and solve them by leveraging distributed systems/big data systems/machine learning systems on top high-performance computing (HPC) clusters and supercomputers
  • Apply studied frameworks and techniques to build real-world data intensive solutions and to systematically evaluate these solutions.

content.fi:
This research project’s learning goal is to familiarize the students with data-intensive computing software stacks (compilers, databases, big data frameworks, modern machine learning frameworks) and optimization techniques to efficiently manage data-center resources (GPUs, CPUs, InfiniBand connection and storage) to solve real-world problems (e.g., training large language models or computing scientific simulation across a large number of GPUs/CPUs). During this course, the students will work on existing tools/frameworks to solve challenging problems over real-world data sets. In addition, the students will learn to collaborate with team members and learn from other tools/frameworks/applications through demonstrations by peers.
For the research activities, the course will introduce a preliminary list of topics. Students are also encouraged to propose their own topics. Supercomputers, HPC clusters, and distributed computing and storage environments will be set up for the course participants (mainly hosted at CSC-IT Center for Science). Depending on the selected topics, students can either work individually or in teams.
The course will provide introductory lecture(s) on how to use environments. The course will run weekly meetings with the students/teams to discuss materials and instructions on the project (introduction to the tool, documentations, research papers, demonstration of the usage). After introductory session(s), the weekly meetings will serve as project update sessions. At the end of the course, the students (teams) are expected to give demonstrations to other student (teams) on their project.

organizationName.en: Department of Computer Science

workload.fi: Luennot, viikottaiset harjoitukset, raportointi
workload.sv: Föreläsningar, veckoövningar, rapportering
workload.en: Lectures, weekly exercises, reporting

learningOutcomes.fi:
• Laboratoriotyöskentely: Opiskelija osaa ottaa käyttöön entuudestaan hänelle tuntemattomia laboratoriolaitteita ja muita komponentteja kuten antureita valmistajan ohjekirjoja ja esitteitä seuraamalla, rakentaa mittalaitteista ja komponenteista yksinkertaisia mittausjärjestelyitä, kerätä ja tallentaa mittausdataa sekä ymmärtää työturvallisuuteen liittyvät perusteet
  • Virheanalyysi: Opiskelija ymmärtää erilaiset mittausvirhetyypit, niiden lähteet ja virheen kasautumisen sekä osaa vertailla eri virhelähteiden suuruuksia
  • Matemaattiset ohjelmistot: Opiskelija hallitsee ainakin yhden tyypillisen ohjelmiston alkeet ja osaa soveltaa sitä mittausdatan analysoimiseen
  • Raportointi: Opiskelija ymmärtää hyvän teknisen raportin rakenteen, osaa laatia teknisiä raportteja käyttäen LaTeXia (Overleaf), kykenee luomaan selkeitä kuvia ja kuvaajia ja liittää ne raporttiin, hallitsee viittausten käyttämisen ja osaa kertoa tuloksista sanallisesti pienelle yleisölle
learningOutcomes.sv:
• Laborationer: Studerande kan ta laboratorieutrustning och andra komponenter, såsom sensorer, i bruk genom att följa tillverkarens manualer och broschyrer, bygga enkla mätarrangemang av mätinstrument och komponenter, samla in och lagra mätdata och förstå grunderna i arbetssäkerhet
  • Felanalys: Studerande förstår olika typer av mätfel, deras källor och ackumulering av fel och kan jämföra storleken på olika felkällor
  • Matematisk programvara: Studenten behärskar grunderna i minst en typisk programvara och kan tillämpa den för analys av mätdata
  • Rapportering: Studenten förstår strukturen i en bra teknisk rapport, kan förbereda tekniska rapporter med hjälp av LaTeX (Overleaf), kan skapa tydliga bilder och grafer och bifoga dem till rapporten, behärskar användningen av referenser och kan kommunicera resultaten muntligt till en liten publik
learningOutcomes.en:
• Laboratory work: The student is able to take laboratory equipment and other components such as sensors into use by following manufacturer's manuals and brochures, build simple measurement arrangements from measuring devices and components, collect and store measurement data, and understand the basics of occupational safety
  • Error analysis: The student understands different types of measurement errors, their sources and accumulation of errors and is able to compare the magnitudes of different error sources
  • Mathematical software: The student masters the basics of at least one typical software and is able to apply it to the analysis of measurement data
  • Reporting: The student understands the structure of a good technical report, is able to prepare technical reports using LaTeX (Overleaf), is able to create clear images and graphs and attach them to the report, masters the use of references and is able to communicate the results verbally to a small audience

content.fi:
• Virta/jännitelähde, yleismittari, oskilloskooppi, kamera, anturit
  • Mittausdata, mittausvirhe, satunnaisvirhe, systemaattinen virhe, virheen kasautuminen
  • Matemaattiset ohjelmistot, funktiosovitus.
  • Tekninen raportointi, LaTeX, Overleaf, viittausten hallinta, kuvat ja kuvaajat

learningOutcomes.fi: In the end of the course, students will be able to apply a scientific approach to problem solving, understand the importance quality and continual improvement in organizations and understand how improvement projects are managed. Student will learn the basics of lean and six sigma tools and understand their linkage to the DMAIC problem solving sequence.

learningOutcomes.en: In the end of the course, students will be able to apply a scientific approach to problem solving, understand the importance quality and continual improvement in organizations and understand how improvement projects are managed. content.fi: Proven method for project management. DMAIC links together Lean Six Sigma tools to a result-driven project management method (DMAIC, Project charter, SIPOC map). Qualitative tools to understand processes. Qualitative tools to understand processes. Practical tools for process mapping, value analysis, and risk analysis (Value Stream Map, Fishbone Diagram, Potential Problem Analysis). Quantitative tools to understand variation. Analytical tools focused on understanding variation and problems in processes (ANOVA, Capability analysis, Gage R&R). Methods to achieve real change in processes. Focus on how to sustain the achieved improvements (Control plan, improvement tools).

learningOutcomes.fi:
This course provides a holistic picture of what founders and managers of modern technology based firms need to consider when establishing, managing and developing businesses. After the course you have a basic understanding of and the ability to systematically explore:
  • a modern and increasingly digital business environment, including platform and sharing economy
  • a modern technology based business organization and projects
  • basic product and process development in scalable digital businesses
  • basic entrepreneurial finance in managing new businesses
  • managing and developing human resources and related venture capabilities
  • important elements and capabilities in managing a modern technology based venture in dynamic and turbulent business environments

content.fi: The focus is on a management and development of a modern technology-based business organization. The course includes lectures on high tech firms, relevant trends, business ecosystems and markets, organization and project management, new product and process development, entrepreneurial finance and human resource development. Special emphasis is on factors of a successful business-level digital transformation strategy and the related capabilities such as organizational change management. Lectures include insights from case studies of real-world business organizations, first-hand experiences from industry guest lecturers and might include site visits to industrial and business environments. The guest lecturers, content, and the case studies vary from year to year.
